channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Toronto Mayor Takes Leave After Admitting Alcohol Abuse
item.description: The admission by Rob Ford that he had “a problem with alcohol” came after the release of a picture that appears to show him smoking crack cocaine.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hunger Striker Ends Fast, but Not Fight, Against Nuclear Power in Taiwan
item.description: A former head of Taiwan’s Democratic Progressive Party thanked protesters for their campaign against a new nuclear power plant and asked them to continue to push for the closure of three others.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Lin Yi-hsiung during his weeklong hunger strike to stop construction on Taiwan's No. 4 nuclear power plant.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 1
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Hindu priests lined up to cast their votes in Ahmedabad, in the western Indian state of Gujarat.

item.title: World Briefing: Toronto Mayor Said to Seek Help
item.description: Citing “a problem with alcohol,” Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto said late Wednesday that he was temporarily stepping aside from his mayoral re-election campaign and seeking “professional help.”
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Qaeda Affiliates Gain Regional Influence as Central Leadership Fades
item.description: The groups are exerting new power in Somalia, Syria, Yemen and West Africa, a State Department report says, challenging counterterrorism officials despite the weaker Qaeda leadership in Pakistan.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Stronger Action Required on Syria, Aid Chief Warns
item.description: Following a barrel bomb attack on a school in Aleppo, the emergency relief coordinator of the United Nations said a Security Council resolution had failed to bring relief to Syrians in need.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Email Suggests White House Strategy on Benghazi
item.description: A 2012 email from Benjamin J. Rhodes, the deputy national security adviser, includes goals for Susan E. Rice’s appearances on TV talk shows and advice on how to discuss the protests that were raging in Libya.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Benjamin J. Rhodes, a national security official, discussed the attack with Susan E. Rice.

item.title: Ukraine Says That Militants Won the East
item.description: Ukraine’s acting president on Wednesday conceded what had long been obvious: The government’s police and security officials had lost control in the areas surrounding the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russian militiamen guarded barricades on Wednesday near Slovyansk, the eastern Ukrainian town where armed men are most firmly in control.

item.title: With Security Tight, Iraqis Cast Votes in Unaccustomed Peace
item.description: Millions defied threats from Islamist extremists to vote for a new Parliament, in what was seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Workers counted ballots under lamplight on Wednesday after a cut in power in Baghdad. The turnout was put at 60 percent.

item.title: Candidate for President in Egypt Tempers His Expectations
item.description: The meager expectations of Hamdeen Sabahi, who is opposing the former general Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi in the race for Egypt’s presidency, illustrate the breakdown of Egypt’s political life since the presidential election two years ago.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Hamdeen Sabahi at a news conference on Wednesday. He finished third in Egypt’s last presidential election, two years ago.

item.title: Children’s Art at Syria School, and Then a Bomb
item.description: Images of the school in Aleppo showed pools of blood and children’s drawings, after a blast that reportedly killed at least 20 people, including 17 students.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Civil Defense staff members at a school in Aleppo, Syria, that was struck by a barrel bomb.

item.title: Gerry Adams Questioned Over Murder From 1972
item.description: Mr. Adams was arrested and questioned Wednesday about the 1972 abduction and murder of a widowed mother of 10, whose body was found on a beach in the Irish Republic in 2003, according to the Sinn Fein website and police.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Gerry Adams in March. His Sinn Fein is a political party once affiliated with the I.R.A.

item.title: Outrage Across Ideological Spectrum in Europe Over Flawed Lethal Injection in U.S.
item.description: The prolonged death of Clayton D. Lockett in Oklahoma produced more than the usual horror in Europe, with Britain and France condemning the execution and calling for the abolition of the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Oklahoma Department of Corrections, via Associated Press

item.title: Tampere Journal: Fans Lose Soccer Team, Then Build Their Own
item.description: When the local club was expelled from play, fans decided to assemble a new one, TamU-K.
item.dc:creator: By MATT NEGRIN
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fans of the TamU-K soccer team cheered at a match last weekend.

item.title: World Briefing: China: Criticism of U.S. Move on Iran
item.description: China on Wednesday sharply criticized an American move to enforce sanctions against Iran that penalized eight Chinese companies and their owner, Li Fangwei, accused of supplying parts for Iranian ballistic missiles.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing : El Salvador: Ex-President Faces Charges
item.description: Former President Francisco Flores will face embezzlement and other corruption charges related to what prosecutors said Wednesday was the misappropriation of at least $5.3 million in loans from Taiwan during his tenure, from 1999 to 2004.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing : Police Kill 1 in Kashmir on Election Day
item.description: The police opened fire in Indian Kashmir on Wednesday, killing one man as small groups opposed to Indian rule and the holding of national elections in the territory threw stones and attacked government vehicles.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Arrest Gerry Adams Over 1972 Murder
item.description: Northern Ireland police are questioning Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams over the 1972 abduction and murder of Jean McConville, his party said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: By One Measure, China Set to Become Largest Economy
item.description: In terms of purchasing power, China’s economy is poised to overtake the United States economy this year, but numbers don’t always tell the entire tale.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A worker carries a shovel near a construction site in Beijing earlier this month.

item.title: Attorney General in Guatemala Excluded From Re-election Bid
item.description: Claudia Paz y Paz, who has taken on a former dictator and top drug traffickers, was left off of a shortlist of candidates to be considered for re-election.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Nigerians Hold Second Day of Protests Over Mass Abductions
item.description: Hundreds of demonstrators marched in the capital to demand that the government do more to find more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by armed militants.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: A protest in Abuja, Nigeria, over the government's failure to rescue scores of girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.

item.title: No Extradition for Franco-Era Police Inspector
item.description: The court on Wednesday ruled that the 13 counts of torture brought against Antonio González Pacheco in Argentina did not qualify as crimes against humanity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA RAFAEL and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Antonio González Pacheco, a former police inspector once known as Billy the Kid, left Madrid's High Court wearing a motorcycle helmet on April 10.

item.title: Up North, on Top: Life in Canada, Home of the World’s Most Affluent Middle Class
item.description: Canadians have their share of complaints, but many also say they’re better off than their American counterparts.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and DAVID LEONHARDT

item.title: An Uneasy Inheritance of India’s Political Dynasty
item.description: Questions are growing in the Indian National Congress party as Rahul Gandhi, the scion of a political dynasty, appears poised to preside over a devastating defeat.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Korean Ferry Students Captured Sinking on Video
item.description: Newly released videos show students’ excitement giving way to fear, confusion and then hopelessness aboard the doomed vessel.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
